title: Chuck Todd takes aim at partisan media
content:
On Media Blog Archives Select Date… December , 2015 November , 2015 October , 2015 September , 2015 August , 2015 July , 2015 June , 2015 May , 2015 April , 2015 March , 2015 February , 2015 January , 2015
NBC 's Chuck Todd took a veiled shot at Fox News chief Roger Ailes , ABC 's George Stephanopoulos , and possibly even himself during an interview this week with the conservative site Breitbart .
Discussing perceptions of media bias , Todd told Breitbart , `` Look , it doesn ’ t help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form . ''
The news executive in question is no doubt Ailes , who spent his early career as a media consultant to Republican presidents Richard Nixon , Ronald Reagan , and George H. W. Bush . But Todd himself served as a staffer on Democratic Senator Tom Harkin 's 1992 presidential bid , and he is surely cognizant of the fact that Stephanopoulos , the host of ABC 's `` This Week '' and his direct competitor on Sunday mornings , formerly served as a senior advisor to Democratic president Bill Clinton .
In the Breitbart interview , John Nolte had told Todd that conservatives `` see the media as a whole as a branch of the Democrat Party out to annihilate us . ''
`` That 's a mindset I ca n't do anything about , '' Todd replied . `` There are some practitioners in the media that view things as a campaign . Look , it doesn ’ t help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form . It 's all winning and losing . ''
Todd 's decision to speak to Breitbart , an aggressively conservative news and opinion site , reflects an effort to broaden the show 's outreach .
`` This is a step in the rehabilitation of my business , '' Todd said at the top of the interview . `` Talk to the critics . Talk to the skeptics . ''
His predecessor , David Gregory , had not been so eager . In an interview with The Huffington Post earlier this year , he said , `` I just made a decision ... There are haters out there . I 'm not going to engage those people , because they 're not looking to have a dialogue with me over Twitter . ''
Chuck Todd should focus more on his declining ratings which have dropped each week since he took over .

On Media Blog Archives Select Date… December, 2015 November, 2015 October, 2015 September, 2015 August, 2015 July, 2015 June, 2015 May, 2015 April, 2015 March, 2015 February, 2015 January, 2015

Chuck Todd takes aim at partisan media

NBC's Chuck Todd took a veiled shot at Fox News chief Roger Ailes, ABC's George Stephanopoulos, and possibly even himself during an interview this week with the conservative site Breitbart.

Discussing perceptions of media bias, Todd told Breitbart, "Look, it doesn’t help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form."

The news executive in question is no doubt Ailes, who spent his early career as a media consultant to Republican presidents Richard Nixon, Ronald Reagan, and George H. W. Bush. But Todd himself served as a staffer on Democratic Senator Tom Harkin's 1992 presidential bid, and he is surely cognizant of the fact that Stephanopoulos, the host of ABC's "This Week" and his direct competitor on Sunday mornings, formerly served as a senior advisor to Democratic president Bill Clinton.

Reached via email, Todd declined to comment.

In the Breitbart interview, John Nolte had told Todd that conservatives "see the media as a whole as a branch of the Democrat Party out to annihilate us."

"That's a mindset I can't do anything about," Todd replied. "There are some practitioners in the media that view things as a campaign. Look, it doesn’t help when any former political operative is involved as a news executive in any form. It's all winning and losing."

Todd's decision to speak to Breitbart, an aggressively conservative news and opinion site, reflects an effort to broaden the show's outreach.

"This is a step in the rehabilitation of my business," Todd said at the top of the interview. "Talk to the critics. Talk to the skeptics."

His predecessor, David Gregory, had not been so eager. In an interview with The Huffington Post earlier this year, he said, "I just made a decision... There are haters out there. I'm not going to engage those people, because they're not looking to have a dialogue with me over Twitter."

UPDATE (6:11 p.m.): A Fox News spokesperson emails:

Chuck Todd should focus more on his declining ratings which have dropped each week since he took over.

Note: This post has been updated to account for the fact that Todd himself was a former Democratic political campaign staffer.
